real.content: Could you summarize the author's experience of learning to ride her own bike? Answer according to: As many of you know 2017 was my first summer riding my own bike. I was always content to ride behind Andy and chat along, take photos and on occasion I even worked, thank god for smart phones where our offices can be where ever we choose them to be. I often get asked why I decided to get my own bike so here it is – I just needed to. A couple of years ago at the end of the season we were out riding and I wanted to go back to look at something so Andy found a parking lot to turn around and for those that ride you know that going slow is when most accidents happen. Well we went down, not hard but hard enough to scare us, once we got our bearings we were able to pick the bike up and ride it home. I rode a bit afterwards and was very nervous and before we knew it it was time to put the bike away for the winter. Well the next spring came I was still having issues with my nerves. A few times Andy could tell that he needed to stop. Without me saying a word he knew I was having an anxiety attack. I was fine when we were flat-out riding but going slow and turning was hard on me and therefore hard on Andy. That summer I still enjoyed the bike but not like before. Once agin, before we knew it it was time to put the bike away for another winter. Enter 2017. When we would drive in the car I had issues. Andy knew it was easier on my if I drove as he started riding in the passenger’s seat more. The spring rolled around and it was time to get out riding I was better but I was still anxious. Canada Day weekend came around and some family invited us to come ride with them up on the Bruce. Well after seeing Andy’s cousin Mary handling her bike and seeing the pure joy it bought her I knew what I was going to do that coming week! For my birthday I went and wrote my M1 – and failed 🙁 I went in not knowing that I had to write my whole G1. I thought because I was already a licensed driver (of over 20 years) that I just would have to write the motorcycle part – I was wrong. I’m happy to say that I got all the questions regarding the motorcycle and road signs right. The only questions I got wrong were the rules around driving with a G1 & G2. Anyway, I went back the next day and secured my M1 and called around to book my bike course. The day after that I bought my very first bike! A Suzuki Marauder 250! While we waited for me to take my M2 course, the weekend of July 21st, Andy would ride my bike down to an empty parking lot and I’d drive the car so I could learn some basics. I really didn’t want to show up at the course and not even know what it felt like to ride my own bike. The one thing that Andy was insistent on was not teaching me to much. He didn’t want to teach me any bad habits that he’d picked up over his years of riding and I was ok with that answer. One thing that I did learn was riding a bike was a lot harder and tiring than I ever thought. By the end of the weekend I was having a blast, turning to the right and left, changing gears, learning emergency stopping. I’m happy to say that at the end of the weekend I passed the ministry test and was on to my M2. What I looked like after 2 hours. I think the bruises on my arms were from my mirrors. It’s the only thing that I could figure out. We continued to ride a lot over the rest of the summer and fall. At the end of September I did my first solo trip to my Dad’s (roughly 3.5 hours away) and when I came back I bought my second bike. I still have a lot of learning to do but am very comfortable riding now and since I’ve started riding my own bike I haven’t had any more anxiety issues when riding. I’m not saying this is the answer for everybody but it was the answer for me.

The author decided to get her own bike after experiencing anxiety attacks while riding with her partner. She failed her first attempt at writing the M1 test, but eventually secured her license and bought a Suzuki Marauder 250. With the help of her partner, she practiced riding in an empty parking lot before taking her M2 course and passing the ministry test. She continued to ride throughout the summer and fall, eventually doing her first solo trip and purchasing a second bike. While she still has more to learn, riding her own bike has alleviated her anxiety issues while riding.

real.content: What are the most common behavioral interventions recommended by psychologists to improve sleep quality in individuals with insomnia?

1. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) – a talk therapy that aims to identify and change negative thoughts and behaviors that contribute to sleep problems.

2. Sleep hygiene – establishing healthy sleep habits such as avoiding caffeine and alcohol, avoiding napping during the day, and creating a routine sleep schedule.

3. Relaxation techniques – practicing deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation to decrease tension and promote relaxation.

4. Stimulus control – establishing a consistent sleep environment by limiting activities other than sleeping in bed, avoiding stimuli like electronic devices or bright lights, and using the bed only for sleep and sex.

5. Sleep restriction – limiting the amount of time spent in bed to increase the sleep drive and build a stronger association between sleep and the bed. 

6. Biofeedback therapy – using electronic devices to monitor and provide feedback on physiological responses to stress and relaxation techniques to promote better sleep habits.

7. Imagery rehearsal therapy – helping individuals identify and address thoughts or worries that interfere with sleep and replacing negative thoughts with positive ones.

8. Light therapy – using bright light exposure to reset the circadian rhythm and promote better sleep quality, especially in individuals with seasonal affective disorder.

real.content: Write a fictional story of at least 500 words about a character who embarks on a journey of self-discovery. Consider including realistic dialogue, vivid descriptions of the setting, and a clear resolution to the character's internal conflict. Additionally, explore the character's motivations and thought processes throughout the journey, and highlight any significant moments or obstacles that they face along the way. Ultimately, the goal of the story should be to illustrate how the character grows and learns about themselves through their journey.

Carla had always felt like something was missing in her life. As a child, she had been happy-go-lucky and full of dreams, but as she grew older, something inside of her began to grow restless. She tried to fill the void with material possessions, new relationships, and even a career change, but nothing seemed to make her truly happy.

One day, Carla decided that enough was enough. She quit her job as a successful lawyer, sold her luxurious condo, and set out on a journey of self-discovery. She had no idea where she was going, but she knew that she had to find the missing piece of her life.

After months of traveling, Carla found herself in a small town in the middle of nowhere. The town was peaceful, with lush green forests and clear lakes. It was a far cry from the hustle and bustle of the city she had left behind. Carla stumbled upon a small bed and breakfast run by a kind elderly couple, and she decided to stay for a while.

Carla spent the first few days exploring the town, reading books, and taking long walks in the forest. She found herself feeling more content than she had in years. But as time passed, Carla began to feel restless again. She wanted answers, and she wasn't going to find them by just sitting around.

One day, Carla met a wise old man named Henry. He was a retired philosopher who had lived in the town for decades. He had a gentle demeanor and a kind smile, and Carla felt drawn to him. She struck up a conversation with him, and before she knew it, they were talking like old friends.

Henry listened intently as Carla told him about her journey and how she was searching for purpose. He looked at her with empathy and began to tell her about his own journey.

"You know, Carla, for so many years, I looked for answers outside of myself," he said. "I read every book, I talked to every person I could, but the answer was always inside of me."

Carla listened intently as Henry continued to speak.

"You won't find what you're looking for out there," he said, gesturing to the world outside. "The answers you seek are inside of you. You just have to be still and listen."

Carla sat with Henry for hours, learning from him and soaking up his wisdom. She began to see things differently, and she realized that Henry was right. The answers she had been searching for were inside of her all along.

As the sun set on her final day in the small town, Carla knew she had found what she was looking for. She had found purpose, and it was within herself. She said her goodbyes to Henry and the elderly couple, and began to make her way back home.

When Carla arrived back in the city, she felt different. She had a new perspective on life, and she realized that the journey she had embarked on had been the most important one of her life. She returned to practicing law, but this time, with a newfound sense of purpose. She took up new hobbies, like painting and writing, and she made new friends who shared her passions.

Carla knew that she would never forget the lessons she had learned on her journey of self-discovery. She had found the missing piece of her life, and it was the most beautiful thing she had ever discovered.

real.content: Analyze the use of biometrics in the hospitality industry.

Biometrics refers to the measurement and analysis of unique physical or behavioral characteristics of an individual. This technology has gained significant use in the hospitality industry, particularly in enhancing guest experience, security, and efficiency of operations. In this text, we analyze the use of biometrics in the hospitality industry.

1. Guest Experience Improvement – Biometrics are used in hotels to check-in guests quickly and efficiently. Facial recognition technology, for instance, allows guests to check-in from their smartphones, which expedites the process. Biometrics have eliminated inefficient check-in procedures where guests have to wait in queues for long periods.

2. Improved Security – Biometrics can provide hotels with better security than traditional methods such as keys, passwords, and swipe cards. Biometric security systems include fingerprint identification for safe deposit boxes, facial recognition software for security cameras, and voice prints for telephone access. This enhanced security helps protect hotel guests' privacy by limiting access to only authorized personnel.

3. Employee Management - In the hospitality industry, biometrics can be used to accurately track employee attendance and work hours. Systems such as fingerprint recognition give management insight into staffing requirements, which means it is easier to schedule and manage human resources.

4. Efficiency of Operations - Biometrics can help hotels to optimize and speed up their processes by automating several operations. Using biometrics in kitchens, for instance, can reduce waste, improve efficiency, and deliver better customer service. In hotel rooms, biometric sensors can adjust lighting and temperature settings automatically, improving guests' comfort and reducing energy bills.

5. Cost Savings – Biometrics can save hotels money by reducing the need for labor-intensive procedures. For example, automated room service orders based on customer preferences eliminate the need for manual order processing. Additionally, biometric access systems to guest rooms can eliminate the need for keys, cards, and lost key replacements.

In conclusion, biometrics has revolutionized the hospitality industry by improving guest experience, security, employee management, and operational efficiency while reducing costs. Adopting biometric technology in the hospitality industry is no longer a luxury but a necessity for organizations looking for a competitive edge.

Michigan has a long history of labor unions dating back to the late 19th century. Workers in industries such as mining, manufacturing, and transportation began forming unions as a way to improve their working conditions and wages. The state's rich natural resources and proximity to major cities made it a hub for industrial growth and, subsequently, labor organizing.

During the early 20th century, labor unions in Michigan gained significant political and economic power. The United Auto Workers (UAW) was founded in Detroit in 1935 and became one of the most powerful unions in the country. The UAW's leadership, including Walter Reuther, played a key role in the New Deal coalition and the Democratic Party's dominance in Michigan politics.

The UAW's influence extended beyond the workplace to shape social and political issues in the state. In the 1960s and 1970s, the union supported civil rights and anti-war movements and played a major role in promoting environmental protection and workers' rights.

The decline of the auto industry in the 1980s and 1990s led to a decline in union membership and influence in Michigan. However, unions have continued to play a significant role in the state's politics and economy, organizing workers in healthcare, education, and other industries.

Overall, labor unions in Michigan have been instrumental in improving working conditions and wages for workers, promoting social and political issues, and shaping the state's economic and political landscape.

Question/Instruction: In what ways did Trebek's performance as moderator affect the post-debate reactions of viewers, and how might this influence the upcoming election?

Given material: Moderator Alex Trebek speaks during a gubernatorial debate between Democratic Gov. Tom Wolf and Republican Scott Wagner in Hershey , Pa., Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. The debate was hosted by the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry.
It's hard to decisively win a 45-minute gubernatorial debate: There's simply not enough time to make key points and thoroughly own the issues.
But you can certainly lose the debate, especially if you're the moderator.
That's what happened Monday night at the Hershey Lodge, when Jeopardy! host Alex Trebek made a guest appearance as celebrity moderator of Pennsylvania's one and only debate between Gov. Wolf, a Democrat, and Republican Scott Wagner.
The debate started late as Trebek lingered on stage during a "fireside chat" with Gene Barr, president of the state Chamber of Business and Industry, which hosted the event. Then, when the main event finally came, the game-show host filibustered and monopolized the whole thing — which seemed fine to the front-runner Wolf but cut into Wagner's attempt to capitalize on a statewide audience for the lone debate.
Trebek abandoned a veneer of impartiality when it came to whether Pennsylvania should impose a severance tax on natural gas drilling. Wolf has pushed the tax since he took office in 2015, but the GOP-led legislature has blocked his efforts. Wagner and other Republicans note that Pennsylvania already imposes an "impact fee" on drillers.
Wagner marshaled that argument Monday, but Trebek suggested it wasn't enough.
That was a remarkably unpopular opinion to push to the Chamber of Business and Industry crowd, which responded with boos. "What did I tell you guys at the beginning?" Trebek said (his one rule: no booing or hissing).
"If all of the voters were to believe everything you've said about each other, we'd have trouble voting for either one of you," Trebek told the candidates. Fair enough — voters often say they're sick of attack ads. But Trebek came across as moralizing, and it's not clear why his opinion should matter to Pennsylvania voters.
At one point, Trebek asked: "Have you ever said anything negative about your opponent that you knew was not true?"
Wagner shook his head no, and Wolf offered a lawyerlike equivocation: "Not that I remember, no."
Trebek began to frame a question about redistricting, noting that the legislature had made scores of amendments to a reform bill and suggesting lawmakers had no interest in actually changing the process.
Then he said the only institution less popular in the Keystone State than the legislature was the Catholic Church, which, of course, has been under fire since a grand jury in August reported decades of abuse by predator priests.
The audience seemed to let out an audible cringe.
"Don't go there," Trebek said, before launching into a soliloquy about his time at a Catholic boarding school.
As Trebek moved on, Wolf interjected, to laughter, "I don't think you quite finished on the redistricting."
The Pennsylvania Cable Network is not the place for this. If you watch PCN, you're expecting the sometimes dry and technical but important details of state government policy debate. Callers to a post-debate review show were aghast at Trebek's performance, no matter which gubernatorial candidate they supported.

According to the given material, Alex Trebek's performance as moderator in the Pennsylvania gubernatorial debate did not go well. He was criticized for monopolizing the debate, abandoning impartiality, and making unpopular opinions known, particularly about the severance tax on natural gas drilling. His moralizing behavior also did not sit well with some viewers. Trebek's performance may influence the upcoming election in Pennsylvania, as it was the only debate between the candidates. However, it remains to be seen how much of an impact his performance will have, especially given the criticism it received.

I wiped my brow with the back of my hand, feeling the hot sweat trickling down the side of my face. It was sweltering, no doubt about that. And yet, even in these suffocating temperatures, a six-year-old girl was missing.

I scanned the crowds of the bustling city, trying to calm the knots in my stomach. I'd been a detective for years, but this was different - this time, I was desperate to find her. This little girl, snatched away by some monster, was someone's daughter, someone's sister. And I was the one tasked with finding her.

I trudged through the streets, my eyes darting from person to person, trying to catch any sign of the girl or her abductor. But the city was a maze, and we were barely sure of where to start.

Hours turned into days, and with each passing moment, the sense of desperation grew stronger. We had narrowed down the possible suspects, but it felt like we were missing something crucial. I felt like I was chasing my own tail, going around in circles, with a growing sense of unease.

And then, one hot, buzzing afternoon, the call came in. They'd found her.

I ran through the city streets, my heart pounding in my chest. When I finally reached the scene, I saw the kidnapper standing there, smirking at me, surrounded by the little girl and her family.

In an instant, I charged forward, tackling him to the ground. A brief struggle ensued, but finally, I cuffed him and dragged him away. I could feel the little girl clutching onto me, safe and sound.

It was a victory, but it felt hollow. We had found the girl, but we could never bring back the moments of terror and anguish that she and her family had gone through. Even now, I could feel the aftermath of the case clinging to me, the sense of loss and horror.

It was a reminder that, no matter how hardened you become to the world, there were some things that would always cut through you like a knife. But for that little girl, it was worth it. She was safe, and I was reminded that the fight was always worth it, even when the odds seemed impossible.

real.content: What is the significance of lighting in theater productions, and how can it be used to emphasize certain concepts or themes in a play? Can you provide examples of notable productions where lighting played a significant role?

Lighting is a crucial element in theatre productions as it sets the mood and atmosphere of the play, highlights the characters and their actions, and emphasizes the central themes of the performance. Lighting design is an art that requires careful consideration and planning to ensure that the lighting complements the other elements of the production seamlessly.

Here are some ways in which lighting can enhance and emphasize certain concepts or themes in a play:

- Mood and Atmosphere: Lighting can create a specific mood and atmosphere in a play, such as a romantic or ominous mood. For example, the use of dimly lit or red lighting can create a tense and eerie atmosphere in a horror or thriller play, while bright lighting can emphasize the joy and happiness in a comedy or musical.

- Character Representation: Lighting can also highlight and emphasize the characteristics of the characters in the play. The use of bright and warm lighting can represent a kind-hearted and positive character, while dim and cold lighting can imply deceit or malice in a character.

- Symbolism: Lighting can be used symbolically to represent specific themes or ideas. For instance, the use of shadows and light contrasts can represent the themes of good and evil or light and darkness.

Some notable productions where lighting played a significant role include:

- Hamilton: The lighting in Hamilton used warm and cool contrasting colors to represent the different characters' perspectives and emotions throughout the play. The use of intense and bright lighting during the iconic "It's Quiet Uptown" scene added to the emotional intensity of the moment.

- The Phantom of the Opera: The use of moody, dim lighting in The Phantom of the Opera added to the eerie atmosphere of the play and enhanced the mysterious nature of the titular character. The interplay of light and shadows during the iconic chandelier moment added to its dramatic effect.

- Les Misérables: The use of dynamic lighting in Les Misérables emphasized the play's themes of conflict and revolution, representing the stark contrast between the poor and rich societies. The use of bright lighting during the song "Do You Hear The People Sing" added to its inspirational and patriotic message.

In conclusion, lighting is a vital component of theatre productions that can significantly impact the audience's experience. Through careful planning and execution, the lighting design can effectively highlight the play's themes, create an atmosphere, and amplify the emotions of the performance.

One example of a production that uses lighting to convey a message is "The Great Gatsby." The lighting designer created a dramatic shift from the opening scene, which was set in a dimly lit room with a single candle, to a bright and lively scene set in a bustling city square. The use of light and shadow creates a sense of tension and excitement as the characters move through the streets, while also emphasizing the contrast between their luxurious lifestyles and the harsh realities of the world around them.

This technique allows the audience to focus on the characters' emotions rather than just the action on the stage.

Finally, "The Lion King" has been praised for its innovative use of lighting to convey the theme of unity and acceptance among diverse cultures.
